Here was my opinion on this relic from last month:

--

The Forbidden Fruit boss relic is a clever idea but in my initial opinion should not exist. 

What makes Slay the Spire repeatedly fun and exciting is that you have to adapt to what you get and can't pick the exact cards you need. If Forbidden Fruit is good enough to take, it undermines this core fun proposition of the game and channels the player toward something they have already done before and know is strong. It has the possibility to make different runs too same-y and also exacerbates any balance problems on individual cards that might exist, but not be serious if they don't show up every run.

On top of that it possibly takes a long while to execute and is probably impenetrable to a new player on one of their first runs, who now has to read and understand the entire card pool.

I think this is a cool relic to read and a fun and original idea, but probably not good for the game overall. I only just first ran into it so take these opinions with a grain of salt.


--

With further experience that opinion has only strengthened; it means you more often get whatever the worst balanced cards currently are and homogenizes runs more, I think, than any other option in the game. (It has always fetched a Dark Lord Form for me, and represents a big fraction of my such runs.)
If this relic is good, it isn’t good for the game. And if it isn't good, well, it's not good.
I don't think forbidden fruit is ever going to win any run on its own barring broken cards which shouldn't exist anyways or taking a missing piece of an infinite.

I'm not saying it is necessarily wildly overpowered, but that it markedly exacerbates any other overpowered cards, makes runs more like each other and less varied and improvisational, and thus makes the game overall less fun.

I find that I take different cards depending on whatever archetype my deck is representing rather than the same cards every time whenever I find it. A run where I would take stasis engine would be very different from a run where I would take spheric shield for instance
I agree, leads to samey runs and tried strategies
it's definitely a fun thing to try a couple times, at least as an experienced player, but yeah, it doesn't seem to work well in StS's format

I largely agree with SamLL on this one. Forbidden fruit definitely feels too homogenizing. Being able to have that much control over exactly how you build your deck is really powerful, and tends to make runs feel samey. Not really sure what the best possible fix is, but anything that gives the player less control would be a step in the right direction. The closest comparison we have is orrery (It used to be a boss relic at one point, and still gave you 5 card rewards simultaneously). Orrery gave/gives you a lot of ability to shape the direction of your run, several opportunities to find key cards, and has the added benefit of letting all the decisions being made together (You can look at every card reward screen, and by pressing skip, see the other cards on offer as well before making any decisions about what you are adding). Fruit on the other hand gives you 3 laser specific card rewards, whatever the best common, uncommon, and rare are in your pool.

I just don't think having that level of control over your card picks is healthy for the game, because at its core STS is about putting the player into unique and interesting situations/puzzles where they have to make the best of whatever tools are being made available to them to solve a difficult and intricate problem. Adaption and improvisation are critical component of what makes STS really fun, rewarding, and enjoyable to me. Part of why I dislike watcher so much is because their strongest playstyle is based around trying to force variations of specific combos/infinites that let you just steamroll the entire game, and over 2/3rds of their card pool is close to worthless (You absolutely can play them in other ways, but I believe it's pretty suboptimal to do so). I would imagine watcher would take cut though fate/flurry of blows, rushdown, and scrawl nearly every time. Ironclad could take true grit/dark embrace/corruption and force one of their strongest combos every time. I don't think this much choice is healthy.

I suggest a nerf/change where you get to either...
1. Look at multiple rare card reward screens simultaneously (3)?
2. Multiple card reward screens with all upgraded cards simultaneously (5)?
3.  Something like prayer wheel, but maybe it works in all fights (All fights have an additional card reward screen)

I have an idea I think is cool:
given how this fruit is called "forbidden"
perhaps it could give you offclass card rewards

Yes, a Prismatic Shard type effect, but at boss relic level strength, is a hilarious idea. I still don't think it's a good idea to make you pick from the entire card pool, especially in offclass (way too slow and too much reading). 

Off the wall suggestion: it's an energy relic that also adds X (3?) random cards from only other classes as its drawback, sort of like a wild [[mark of pain]] with possible big upside. (Maybe that doesn't look like enough of a drawback? But you will get some stinkers.)

Alternately, maybe you get N (all rare? forced rarity, e.g., 2 rare 2 uncommon 2 common?) card picks, each from a different random offclass? Could that ever be boss relic worthy?

This relic being new makes it hard to judge for me, as a boss relic you don't see it very often. But my first impressions is that this relic kinda sucks. I don't need to select 3 specific cards to make a good deck in downfall, if i want a good deck I would much rather deck an energy relic, a relic that can remove/transform bad cards or a relic that offers a buff every turn (so like bowler hat, snecko eye, pyramid). I would take this over other bottom tier boss relics like tiny house at least.
Also +8 max HP on this relic feels like an arbitrary way to make it a little bit better; the only other boss relic that does more then one thing is tiny house.
